projectDesc.p: To the tune “Midnight Joy”—"Frozen Clouds" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Midnight Joy”—"Frozen Clouds"
Frozen clouds dim the sky,
A thin boat
Departs the riverside on a whim,
And crosses a thousand valleys and a thousand canyons.
In the depth of Yue streams,
Raging waves gradually die down,
A favorable wind suddenly rises.
I then hear the traveling tradesmen calling to each other.
The lone sail hangs high;
On a floating boat,
I swiftly pass the southern bank.
Before my eyes, the wine shop banner swings,
A small village wreathed in smoke,
And rows of frosty trees.
The setting sun retreats,
The fishermen strike the side of the boat and return.
Withered lotuses fall apart,
Fading willows cover and reveal.
On the bank, in pairs of two or three,
Girls are doing laundry.
Avoiding the travelers,
Shy, they smile, chatting to each other.
Being here brings back my thoughts.
I have abandoned the embroidered chamber.
Like a duckweed in the waves, I have nowhere to stay.
I sigh at the thought of reunion,
who can now believe in the earnest words that were said back then?
Wretched is the parting heart,
Vainly regretting that the year has come to an end and the time to return home has been delayed.
I let my watery eyes gaze
At the long, distant road to the capital.
The cry of the wild goose resounds, lingering in the vast evening sky.
